image.altText: Skyspan umbrella at Cairns School of Distance Education on left, school building with ramps on right

items.synopsis: Education Queensland has admitted to destroying trees planted in memory of deceased teachers as part of spending blitz at distance education school.

title.children: Queensland’s second largest school builds $700k playground despite nearly all 4,300 students learning from home

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian and Daryl Maguire

items.synopsis: The New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption hands down its findings into former NSW premier Gladys Berejiklian and former Liberal MP, Daryl Maguire. Follow the key moments live in our blog.

title.children: ICAC delivers serious corrupt conduct findings against Berejiklian, Maguire

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption has handed down its findings into former NSW premier Gladys Berejiklian and former Liberal MP, Daryl Maguire. It has made findings of corrupt conduct against two individuals, the former premier and Mr Maguire. The report was delivered to parliament about 9:15am this morning, almost two years after Ms Berejiklian resigned from the state's top job. More to come.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICAC finds corrupt dealings of 'two individuals'

children.content: The New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption has handed down its findings into former NSW premier Gladys Berejiklian and former Liberal MP, Daryl Maguire.
It has made findings of corrupt conduct against two individuals, the
former premier and Mr Maguire.
The report was delivered to parliament about 9:15am this morning, almost two years after Ms Berejiklian resigned from the state's top job.
More to come.

image.altText: Olympic house in Lausanne

items.synopsis: Brisbane Games organisers travelled to IOC headquarters in Switzerland for the first of many catch-ups to discuss 2032 Games preparations.

title.children: IOC told 2032 Brisbane Olympics and Gabba redevelopment plans are 'on track'

image.altText: A group of PNG women and babies sitting on a verandah

items.synopsis: A group of bandits that kidnapped an Australian professor in the PNG Highlands appears to have struck again, this time snatching and assaulting a group of women and girls. Warning: Readers might find the details in this story distressing.

title.children: The PNG gang that kidnapped an Australian professor may now be unleashing new horrors on teen girls

image.altText: Debris from the Titan submersible recovered from the ocean floor.

items.synopsis: "Presumed" human remains are recovered from within the shattered hulk of a submersible that imploded while on a voyage to the century-old wreck of the Titanic earlier this month.

title.children: 'Presumed' human remains recovered inside debris from imploded Titan submersible as wreck parts returned to shore

title.children: 'They made a huge error': Amber wouldn't have taken on so much debt if she hadn't trusted the RBA

image.altText: Vladimir Putin looking contemplatively upwards

items.synopsis: The Wagner mutiny will slowly, over time, corrode the fighting power of the Russian military. And the Ukrainians, who know the Russian military better than anyone on the planet, will be sure to exploit this, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Physical, intellectual and moral: Three ways the Wagner mutiny will impact Russian fighting power

image.altText: Protesters and cricketers tangle while orange smoke fills the air

title.children: Five quick hits — protesters disrupt play and England gets a taste of Travball

image.altText: Giles sits cross-legged on the floor of his apartment. He uses one hand to push his head towards his shoulder.

items.synopsis: Australian researchers call for an end to the use of opioids to treat acute back and neck pain after finding they are no more effective than a placebo.

title.children: Opioids don't help acute back and neck pain — and could be harmful, research finds

image.altText: Taylor Swift sings into a microphone while performing on stage.

image.altText: man smiling with thumbs up in bed

title.children: In a traumatic accident, Sean's skull dislocated from his spine. He now lives with 'the invisible disability'

image.altText: A side shot of a man's face and neck.

items.synopsis: Not so long ago, the idea of a National Anti-Corruption Commission was dismissed as a "fringe issue" by Scott Morrison. No-one is suggesting that now, writes David Speers.

title.children: Will Stuart Robert be one of the new National Anti-Corruption Commission's first targets?

image.altText: Pedestrians

items.synopsis: Australia's stock market expected to open fairly flat, with retail trade and job vacancies data for May out this morning providing an update on how much interest rates rises are slowing the economy. Follow the latest live on our markets blog.

title.children: ASX set for flat start, retail trade and job vacancies data out today

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US treasury secretary Janet Yellen is using remarkably similar language to Australia's Reserve Bank (or perhaps it's the other way around!). She has said the US is on a "path" to reducing inflation while maintaining a strong jobs market. Indeed, she sounds a bit more optimistic than Philip Lowe and others at the Reserve Bank who describe that path in Australia as "narrow". Here's some highlights of what Dr Yellen had to say to Stephanie Ruhle on MSNBC show The 11th Hour, in an interview that will air shortly in the United States. " Inflation year-over-year has come down for 11 months in a row and is now down by about 5 per cen t," she said. "Granted, it remains too high, and the labor market is strong, but, in part, we're seeing the strong job market is attracting more people into it. "The share of working-age Americans that are participating in the labor market is higher than it's been in, I believe, 15 years. So some easing is coming from additional participation in the labor market. "And headline growth in the economy has slowed. And that means that firms are reconsidering just how many additional workers they need to hire. And as they're now planning for somewhat slower growth — after all, we are operating at capacity and back to full employment — as they anticipate slower growth and some sectors experiencing some weakness, job openings — while still very, very high — are declining. "And a little bit of reduced pressure from firms that have such ambitious hiring plans is taking some of the heat out of competition in the labor market. "So wage increases remain very solid, but they've come down off their highs. And that will be a factor even in the context of a strong labor market that — that will tend to reduce inflation over time. "So I don't believe we need to see any very significant weakening of the labor market. I think, as I've said repeatedly, there's a path for inflation to come down in the context of the strong labor market, and I think we're seeing that. We're on that path, but it will take time." The Reserve Bank here has also said that it doesn't want to give up all the jobs gains Australia has made over the pandemic period that saw unemployment drop from being consistently above 5 per cent before the pandemic to 3.6 per cent currently. However, the RBA in its forecasts and speeches has admitted that it expects unemployment will probably need to rise to 4.5 per cent for inflation to come back under control within the 2-3 per cent target range. Our blog master today, Gareth Hutchens, wrote a great piece on this on Sunday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Yellen says US economy still on 'path' to lower inflation without soaring unemployment

featuredLink.title: The Reserve Bank wants more unemployment. It should be applauded for admitting it

children.content: US treasury secretary Janet Yellen
is using remarkably similar language to Australia's Reserve Bank (or perhaps it's the other way around!).
She has said the US is on a "path" to reducing inflation while maintaining a strong jobs market.
Indeed, she sounds a bit more optimistic than Philip Lowe and others at the Reserve Bank who describe that path in Australia as "narrow".
Here's some highlights of what Dr Yellen had to say to
Stephanie Ruhle on MSNBC show The 11th Hour
, in an interview that will air shortly in the United States.
Inflation year-over-year has come down for 11 months in a row and is now down by about 5 per cen
t," she said.
"Granted, it remains too high, and the labor market is strong, but, in part, we're seeing the strong job market is attracting more people into it.

"The share of working-age Americans that are participating in the labor market is higher than it's been in, I believe, 15 years. So some easing is coming from additional participation in the labor market.

"And headline growth in the economy has slowed. And that means that firms are reconsidering just how many additional workers they need to hire. And as they're now planning for somewhat slower growth — after all, we are operating at capacity and back to full employment — as they anticipate slower growth and some sectors experiencing some weakness, job openings — while still very, very high — are declining.
"And a little bit of reduced pressure from firms that have such ambitious hiring plans is taking some of the heat out of competition in the labor market.
"So
wage increases remain very solid, but they've come down off their highs
. And that will be a factor even in the context of a strong labor market that — that will tend to reduce inflation over time.
"So
I don't believe we need to see any very significant weakening of the labor market
. I think, as I've said repeatedly, there's a path for inflation to come down in the context of the strong labor market, and I think we're seeing that. We're on that path, but it will take time."

The Reserve Bank here has also said that it doesn't want to give up all the jobs gains Australia has made over the pandemic period that saw unemployment drop from being consistently above 5 per cent before the pandemic to 3.6 per cent currently.
However,
the RBA
in its forecasts and speeches has admitted that it
expects unemployment will probably need to rise to 4.5 per cent
for inflation to come back under control within the 2-3 per cent target range.
Our blog master today,
Gareth Hutchens
, wrote a great piece on this on Sunday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Yesterday, the ASX saw its best-one day rise since April after the Bureau of Statistics said we'd had a surprising decline in monthly inflation. And this morning, the ASX200 futures suggest Australia's share market will open slightly lower, after European stocks made gains overnight but while US stock markets have had a mixed session. We’ll be getting some important local data from the Bureau of Statistics today at 11.30am: Retail trade (for May) Job vacancies (for May) Australian National Accounts: Finance and Wealth (March quarter) On that last one, household wealth declined by $57 billion in the December quarter 2022, marking the third consecutive quarter of declining wealth - largely due to falling residential property prices. We'll find out today what happened in the March quarter.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the ASX open higher?

children.content: Good morning,
Yesterday, the ASX saw its best-one day rise since April after the Bureau of Statistics said we'd had a surprising decline in monthly inflation.
And this morning, the ASX200 futures suggest Australia's share market will open slightly lower, after European stocks made gains overnight but while US stock markets have had a mixed session.
We’ll be getting some important local data from the Bureau of Statistics today at 11.30am:
Retail trade (for May)
Job vacancies (for May)
Australian National Accounts: Finance and Wealth (March quarter)

On that last one, household wealth declined by $57 billion in the December quarter 2022, marking the third consecutive quarter of declining wealth - largely due to falling residential property prices.
We'll find out today what happened in the March quarter.

title.children: 'The most fun part of science': Scientists discover a planet that should not exist
